I've also hit this. I notice I can access an ambassador endpoint by, say: <denchmark-code>curl -v -u ${USER}:${PASSWORD} https://${DEPLOYMENT}.endpoints.${PROJECT}.cloud.goog/ambassador/v0/diag/ </denchmark-code>
But not seeing a convenient way to port-forward and make requests without credentials as <denchmark-link:https://github.com/kubeflow/examples/search?q=port-forward&unscoped_q=port-forward>several of the example notebooks do</denchmark-link>

Ambassador is used both as a reverse proxy and to ensure all requests have credentials when basic auth is used. Options are
Disable basic auth (and remove external ip) if you want to kubectl port-forward to ambassador with no credentials Attach credentials to the request Deploy a proxy like nginx and use that to attach basic auth headers and then port-forward to that
Port forwarding to the individual services like the examples are doing should work. Credential checking happens in Ambassador; so if you bypass ambassador (e.g. port-forward to mnist service or katib) then that application will not check for credentials. See related issues for more context; explanation.
